title: Matthew Rocklin
description: Personal site of Matthew Rocklin - thoughts on open source, startups, and engineering

items.title: Working Notes
items.content_html: I work in the Python data ecosystem, building tools like Dask and Coiled. I write about the technical and human aspects of this work.

items.title: Beginning Again
items.content_html: Everyone feels behind on AI, but no one is ahead. That shared beginner status is what makes this moment so fun.

items.title: Multi-Agent Workflows
items.content_html: Exploring multi-agent AI workflows—what works, what doesn't, and lessons from playing Diplomacy with Claude agents.

items.title: AI Zealotry
items.content_html: Senior engineers are best positioned to benefit from AI. We're good enough to avoid slop, and there's so much we can accomplish. I wouldn't go back.

items.title: Audio-Visual Setup
items.content_html: How we present ourselves has unreasonable effectiveness on perception. An excellent Zoom setup costs $2000 and a day—anyone can achieve the unfair advantage that tall people have naturally.

items.title: Avoid Indirection
items.content_html: Abstraction has costs. Every layer you add is another place readers have to look. Sometimes the clearest code is the most direct.

items.title: Biased Benchmarks
items.content_html: Fair benchmarks are surprisingly difficult even with best intentions. We judge others by our objectives, fail to use their projects with expertise, and gravitate toward cases where we excel.

items.title: Short attention span
items.content_html: Speaking truth is easy. Getting people to listen is hard. Practical advice on respecting your reader through an attention span budget.

items.title: I Walked across Spain
items.content_html: Reflections from 27 days and 500 miles across Spain. The overlapping physical, social, cultural, and spiritual layers that make this pilgrimage meaningfully different.

items.title: Cloud Computing is Broken
items.content_html: What hunger am I seeing on the ground? Boring shit. People struggle most with the basics of cloud computing. The promise remains undelivered.

items.title: Decision Fatigue
items.content_html: When you hit a roadblock, don't ask "what should we do?" Own the problem. Propose a solution. Help your team by carrying the weight yourself.

items.title: Listen to Sell
items.content_html: Resist the urge to answer technical questions. We want to show off how things work, but we often dive too deep before understanding the customer's actual problem.

items.title: Twitter, LinkedIn, and Failing in Public
items.content_html: LinkedIn shows only the final act. We connect to heroes during their struggles, not their victories. The solution: fail heroically in public.

items.title: Failure
items.content_html: Someone has to pay the psychological cost of uncertainty. I choose honesty, even when it has negative consequences.

items.title: Small Scope Reviews
items.content_html: A fast review cycle is incredibly valuable. Distinguish obligatory comments that stop regressions from commendable ones that add enhancements. Better is the enemy of good.

items.title: How GitHub taught me to Micromanage
items.content_html: Open source code review taught me to give intense, detailed feedback. Then I became a manager and learned why that doesn't always translate.

items.title: Hammers and Nailguns
items.content_html: A nailgun puts nails into wood. A hammer whacks things. Simple tools with humble opinions are more versatile than specialized ones.

items.title: Hiring Sales
items.content_html: We fired the sales team when our product was bad. Now it's good. Finding the right early sales hire is an interesting challenge.

items.title: How I Conduct an Interview
items.content_html: My approach to 45-minute interviews: what I share, what I ask, and how I evaluate candidates. Useful for interviewers or anyone interviewing with me.
